title: FirstFT: Americans rush to secure vaccine boosters
text:
How well did you keep up with the news this week? Take our quiz.

Residents of America's biggest cities are struggling to book vaccine appointments because of the rising wave of the Omicron coronavirus variant and a rush in demand for booster shots before Christmas.

Walgreens, one of the country's biggest pharmacy chains by number of pharmacists, said it was observing record levels of demand, while those looking to book appointments in some localities are having to wait as long as two weeks.

Experts warn that the lack of appointments in some regions will mean the heavily mutated new strain will spread more quickly in the US than it has in the UK, where daily cases are at record levels.

Some cities have set up walk-in centres for people to receive boosters without an appointment. But they are often limited in both location and opening times, leading to long queues outside.

Have you had difficulty booking a booster jab? Email me at firstft@ft.com. Thank you for reading FirstFT Americas. Here's the rest of today's news — Gordon

Five more stories in the news

1. Central banks act to curb inflation The Bank of Japan today became the latest central bank to announce it is preparing to scale back pandemic-era support. The Japanese central bank said it will taper all corporate debt and commercial paper purchases. Yesterday, the Bank of England announced a surprise interest rate increase, the first in more than three years, as it responds to surging inflation. The European Central Bank also said it would scale back its crisis bond-buying a day after the Federal Reserve outlined a more hawkish stance towards inflation.

2. Oracle nears deal to buy health IT company Cerner Larry Ellison's company is nearing a deal to acquire the healthcare information technology group for about $30bn, according to people briefed about the matter. The potential deal would be the largest in Oracle's history and deepen its connections with the healthcare industry.

3. TPG joins wave of private equity groups going public The Texas-based group, which has $109bn in assets under management, is the latest in a series of private equity groups that have sought to capitalise on soaring valuations by listing their shares on the stock market.

4. EU to work with allies on possible Russia sanctions EU leaders agreed to co-ordinate with allies over sanctions in the event of an invasion of Ukraine and charged bloc officials with preparing measures that could include cutting Russian banks off from the international Swift network.

5. Turkey raises minimum wage 50% President Recep Tayyip Erdogan announced a 50 per cent rise in the minimum wage to protect citizens from soaring inflation, hours after the central bank cut interest rates for the fourth consecutive month. Some exporters have benefited from a stronger dollar but others are craving certainty after the lira's crash.

Coronavirus digest

  • Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida is to make a press announcement later today following a telephone call with the chief executive of Pfizer concerning supplies of vaccines.

  • After weeks of accusations of sleaze and reports of Covid rule-breaking parties, UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson has suffered a huge blow after his Conservative party lost a parliamentary seat it has held for 200 years.

  • Joe Biden said it could still take “weeks” to secure the final passage of his flagship $1.75tn Build Back Better economic plan.

  • The head of Delta Air Lines said that he expected the Omicron coronavirus variant to affect bookings early next year even as passengers return to the skies for holiday travel.

  • The European Medicines Agency could approve the Novavax two-dose coronavirus vaccine as early as next week. A US panel of scientific advisers has voted to recommend the BioNTech/Pfizer and Moderna vaccines over the shot made by Johnson & Johnson.

The days ahead

Earnings Darden Restaurants, the owner of casual dining chains including Olive Garden and Cheddar's Scratch Kitchen, and RV maker Winnebago Industries report earnings. Investors will be paying close attention to any commentary from the companies on inflation, supply chain issues and early signs of business being affected by the latest wave of coronavirus cases and restrictions sweeping the US.

Monetary policy Federal Reserve board governor Christopher Waller is set to speak on the economic outlook at the Forecasters Club of New York. Separately, Mary Daly, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, will be discussing the 2022 economic outlook during a virtual question-and-answer session hosted by the Wall Street Journal.

Taiwan referendum Saturday's four-question vote on issues ranging from food safety to a nuclear power plant represents a test for the opposition KMT.

Chile presidential run-off The run-off in Sunday's presidential election pits José Antonio Kast, an ultraconservative father of nine and staunch Catholic, against Gabriel Boric, a 35-year-old former student union leader with links to the country's Communist party. The contest has divided Chileans.

Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, World Health Organization director-general, has warned the world faces not just a pandemic but also an “infodemic”. Join FT journalists and experts today on Twitter Spaces to discuss this and whether the way in which we frame the topic of misinformation can influence our capacity to successfully deal with it.

What else we're reading and listening to

Democrats should worry about what's happening in Biden country Georgia helped to tip a bitter presidential contest to the Democrats and it will be decisive in deciding the political fate of Joe Biden. With less than a year until midterm elections, James Politi, the FT's Washington bureau chief, travelled to the state and spoke to voters to get their verdict on the president.

The underside of globalisation On the Rachman Review podcast, Gideon talks to Mark Leonard, director of the European Council on Foreign Relations and author of The Age of Unpeace: How Connectivity Causes Conflict, about how global powers try to exert influence in an interconnected world.

Afghanistan on the brink of famine Millions are facing starvation as the country slides into what the UN has called the world's worst humanitarian catastrophe. The crisis has been brewing for years: decades of fighting disrupted harvests and displaced rural communities and successive droughts have jeopardised food supplies.

From IT sales to calling the shots in crypto land Tether's rapid rise at the heart of the cryptocurrency industry has turned the spotlight on its publicity-shy chief executive Jean-Louis van der Velde and, in particular, his links to a Shenzhen-based company that makes products such as television receivers and amplifiers.

Life & Arts

How to give the perfect Christmas present The winter holiday used to be a riotous public bacchanal, more like Halloween. After two centuries of commercialisation, it seems pointless to resist the tradition. But we can at least aspire to become better gift givers. Tim Harford has some tips.
